headline: Morning Headlines: Ohio redistricting panel charts course to 4th map proposal; Labor dispute between projectionists and CIFF settled
author: Amanda Rabinowitz
sentences:
Here are your morning headlines for Monday, March 21:
Ohio redistricting panel charts course to 4th map proposal
Labor dispute between projectionists, CIFF settled
Akron council expected to pass mayor’s budget
Some Ohio Republicans raise talk about impeaching Chief Justice over redistricting decisions
Deshaun Watson trade done, Browns defend decision to add QB
Ohio redistricting panel charts course to 4th map proposal
(Statehouse News Bureau) -- The Ohio Redistricting Commission is going back to the drawing board after the Ohio Supreme Court rejected its third attempt at state House and Senate district maps.

Cleveland.com reports the agreement reached Saturday between Playhouse Square and the International Association of Theatrical Stage Employees Local 160 says the non-union rental video equipment company hired by the film festival will be the main operators of the equipment, but three union workers will be on-hand to provide technical help throughout the full stretch of the festival.

Some Ohio Republicans raise talk about impeaching Chief Justice over redistricting decisions
(Statehouse News Bureau) -- Some Republican legislators are saying that impeachment charges could be filed against Ohio Supreme Court Chief Justice Maureen O’Connor, who’s sided with the three Democratic justices in throwing out GOP-drawn legislative and congressional maps.

Labor dispute between projectionists, CIFF settled
(Cleveland.com) -- A labor dispute between union film projectionists and the Cleveland International Film Festival has been settled as the festival moves to its new location at Playhouse Square next week.

Deshaun Watson trade done, Browns defend decision to add QB
(WKSU) -- The Cleveland Browns front office is responding to the controversy over the trade for quarterback Deshaun Watson, after a weekend of uproar on social media.

Cleveland.com reported last week that union workers, which have a contract with Playhouse Square, won’t be running the projectors for the film festival because of a possible loophole in a collective bargaining agreement.

Meanwhile, the Cleveland Rape Crisis center issued a statement Saturday saying the trade decision was triggering for many in the community and encouraged those in need of support to contact the center.
The Democrat who defeated Cupp in 2012 as he sought re-election, former justice Bill O’Neill, says he’s stunned at the idea, and he and retired Republican justice Paul Pfeifer say it won’t happen.

Akron council expected to pass mayor’s budget
(WKSU) -- Akron City Council is expected to move quickly in adopting Mayor Dan Horrigan’s proposed operating budget for the year.
They say they talked with Watson in person about his priorities before making the decision, along with general manager Andrew Berry and head coach Kevin Stefanski.
In a statement Sunday, Browns owners Dee and Jimmy Haslam say they are "aware and empathetic to the highly personal sentiments expressed" about the trade.
Up to this point, Republican and Democratic legislative caucuses have drafted separate plans, then presented the proposals to the commission.
On the spending side, the mayor proposes adding to both the police and fire departments, adding new blood from its training academies.
The commission initiated a plan to have Republican and Democratic mapmakers draft new state legislative district maps together.
While property tax revenue is expected to be stable for 2022, Horrigan’s budget projects a 3% drop in income tax receipts.
But House Speaker and Ohio Redistricting Commission Chairman Bob Cupp said over the weekend he had no comment.
He has denied wrongdoing, and the Haslams say they will respect due process as his legal proceedings continue.
The three sets of plans adopted by the commission and rejected by the court were all Republican-drawn maps.
After hearings last week, the full council is expected to take up discussion when it meets Monday.
If it’s approved, this year’s operating budget would be a 4% increase over last year.
Cupp was an Ohio Supreme Court justice from 2007-2013, serving alongside O’Connor.
The commission took the first steps this weekend at a new bipartisan process.
The budget includes $65 million in additional federal COVID-19 relief funds.
A grand jury declined to indict him on criminal charges earlier this month.
There’s also a planned increase in the number of public service personnel.
The plan is to hold the line on water and sewer rates for the year.
The commission has until March 28 to adopt a fourth set of maps.
But Watson faces 22 civil lawsuits alleging sexual misconduct.
The festival instead will use non-union Playhouse employees.
They say they found him "humble, sincere and candid."
Mike DeWine said impeachment is “not a good idea”.
Fellow commission member and Republican Gov.
